title: So far so good!! 2009 Chevy Suburban 2500 LT
description: So far so good! I have a 2009 Chevy Suburban 2500 LT with just a lil over 150K miles on the engine and decided to try the Valvoline High Mileage 150K Synthetic oil for my Florida Road Trip, starting from the North East Coast driving to the southwest coast of Florida.. I have to say right now this is hands down the best oil I have ever used for a high mileage engine. My Suburban has the common Chevy LS engine oil consumption problem and the agonizing Low Oil Pressure gauge reading. I also had a check engine light on that I had on for months. Before my trip I took my Surburban to my mechanic and instructed him to use this oil I purchased. Did the oil change and guess what.. After a few hundred miles of driving south towards my destination, the check engine light turned off and the oil pressure seems to be normal.  Drove about 1200 miles checked the oil and I was shocked.  Right now It looks to be working really well and not consuming oil the way it was before where I had to constantly monitor and add Valvoline Synthetic 5w30 oil. Will be using this from now on with 3K oil Change intervals…

title: Piece-of-mind lubrication in your pavement pounder!
description:
I've had a LOT of beaters over the years.  This has been the first task on all of them the day they first hit my garage:  Valvoline High Mileage Synthetic Blend with Lucas Oil Stabilizer and a Fram Tough Guard filter.  Of all the beaters I've had, none died from an oil related failure.  I have also found over the years some cheaper/generic oils in a burner/leaker tends to burn/leak worse.  Perfect middle-of-the line price point for piece-of-mind lubrication in your pavement pounder!  I have put 200k+ on Mopar v8's to Ford 4 cylinders.  My personal record was 344k on a Mopar 3.0 v6 Dodge Grand Caravan - she went to the bone yard due to excessive and flat out dangerous frame rot, and was driven there under her own power.  Was it the oil?  Maybe.  More likely religious 3k oil changes.  None the less with 35yrs under the hood, I trust Valvoline and will continue to use it.
***UPDATE 5.24.2021***  I retract nothing from the above, as I do still think Valvoline is a quality product.  However, I have come to recognize there are indeed even BETTER options out there.  I have become an AMSOIL convert, and a 100% believer in the hype.  New vehicles/small engines and rotten old beaters alike in my fleet now receive it.  I won't bash Valvoline - it is what I believe to be the highest quality you can buy in that price range.  None the less, I have upgraded and moved on.....

title: Best oil in my book
description:
I have been doing my own oil changes for years. I have an 2005 Chevy Malibu, with 220K miles on it and still going strong. I've bounced around different oils, generally just using whatever was the most cost effective at the time, with no real concern for brand. However recently I've noticed a serious difference between this and those other conventional oils that I was using. It started with a rough idle that was primarily caused by a ignition coil pack, however after repairing that I noticed the issue, although lessened drastically, was still there a bit, I decided that although I was not quite to the 4K mileage mark, I needed to do an oil change. Oil change done, and the rough idle has gone away. Coincidence? I don't believe so.
Regardless, I am very impressed with this product so far. I also note as others have done, the price on amazon tends to fluctuate, it will go up to around $30 for awhile, then drop to around $18. With prime shipping that is a very good deal. When the price goes higher, I price shop around. Today I found it at Wal-mart locally for $17.74+tax. I bought two just in case. Like others on here, I would recommend putting this on your wish list and waiting for it to drop again, when it does stock up.
